body.div:
Vol. II
Chap I
"It is with difficulty that I remember
the æra of my cr being. All the events of
that period appear confused & indistinct.
I know only that I felt a strange A strange
sensation sea seized me and a it appeared
I saw, felt heard and smelt at the same
time and it was indeed a long time be
fore I learned to distinguish between the
various opoperations of my various senses. By degrees
I remember a stronger light pressed upon
my nerves and so that I was obliged to close
my eyes. Darkness then came over me
and troubled me.– But hardly had I felt
this when (by opening my eyes as I now suppose)
the light poured in upon me again– I walked
and I believe descended; but presently I found
a great differencealteration in my sensations; before
dark opaque bodies had surrounded me,
impervious to my touch or sight – and I
now found that I could wander on at liberty
with no obstacles which I could not either
surmount or avoid– The light be became ^more&
more opressive to me and the heat wearying
me as I walked I sought a place where I could
perceiverecieve shade. This was the forest near Ingolstadt,
and here by the side of a brook I lay weary
for some hours ^resting from my fatigue untill I felt tormented by
hunger and thirst. This roused me from my nearly
dormant state and I ate some berries
which I found ^hanging on the trees or lying on
the ground – I slaked my thirst by the
brook and then again lying down I was
overcome by sleep–; It was dark when I
awoke, I felt cold also and half frightened
^as it were instinctively on seein finding myself so desolate.
Before I had quitted your appartment
on a sensation of cold I had covered my
self with some clothes, but these were
notinsufficient to secure me from the
dw dews of night. I was a poor helpless
miserable wretch—I knew no& could
distinguish no nothing but
felt ^feeling pain
invade me on all sides and I sat down
and wept.
Soon a gentle light stole over the
heavens and gave me a sensation of pleasure
I started up, and beheld a radiant form
rise am from among the trees. I gazed with
a kind of wonder – It moved slowly; but
it enlightened my path, and I again
went out in search of berries. I was still
cold when on the ground under one of the
trees I found a huge cloak with which I–
covered myself, and sat down on the ground.
No distinct ideas occupied my mind all was
confused and I felt the light, and hunger
and thirst and darkness; innumerable
sounds rung in my ears and on all sides
various scents saluted me; the only object
that I could distinguish was the bright
moon and I fixed my eyes ion th that with
pleasure. Several changes of day and night
passed and the orb of night had greatly
lessened when I began to distinguish my
sensations ^from each other–. I first saw dis gradually saw plainly the clear stream
that supplied me with drink and the gre
trees that covered ^shaded me with their foliage.
I was delighted when I first discovered
that a pleasant sound thatwhich often
delighte saluted my ears proceeded
from the throats of son the little anihwinged
amnimals who often intercepted the light
from my eyes. I began also to see an
with forms greater accuracy the forms
that surrounded me and to perceive
the boundaries of the radiant light which
overspeaed my dwelling canopied me.–some
times I tried to imitate the pleasant songs of
the birds but was unable— Sometimes I
also wished to express my sensations in
my own mode but the uncouth and innarticu
late sound which broke from me which frightened
me into silence again.
The moon had dissapeared from the night, &
again with a lessened form it shewed itself
again while I still remained in the forest.
My ideas ^sensations were by this time become distinct
&e ^my mind received every day aditional ones ^ideas. My eyes
became accustomed to the light and to
perceive objects in their right forms; I distin
guished theinsect insect from the herb, and by de
grees one herb from a another – I found
that the sparrow uttered none but harsh
notes and butwhilstthat ^those of the blackbird were sweet
and enticing. I had le one day when I was
oppressed by cold I found a fire that
had been left by some wandering beg
gars and was over come with delight. X
X
at the warmth
which I ex-
perienced from
it.
In my joy I thrust my hand into the
live embers but quickly drew it away with a cryin
of
pain– How strange, I thought, that the
same cause should at once produce
such delicious and such u opp opposite
effects –I examined the materials of the
fire, & to my joy found it to be wood –
I quickly collected some branches but
they were wet and would not burn.
I was pained at this and sat still
watching the opperation of the fire.
The wet wood I had placed near the heat
became dy drydried, and itself became became
hot
inflamed. I reflected on this, and by touching
the various branches I discovered the cause
and busied myself in collectionng a great
dealquantity of wood that I might dry it and
have a pel plentiful supply oof fire. When night
came on and ^brought with it sleep, I was in the greatest
fear lest my fire should be extinguished
I covered it carefully with try dry wood
and leaves & then placed upon that wet
branches and then spreading my cloak I la
on the ground I& sunk into sleep. I was morning
when I It was morning when I awoke & my
first care was to visit the fire –I uncovered
it and th a gentle breeze quickly fanned it
into a flame I observed this also and contri
ved a fan of branches which roused the
embers when thy were nearly extinguished.
When night again came I found with plea
sure that the fire gave light as well
as heat and I often and the discovery of this
element was useful to me also in my food–
for I found some of offals that the travel
lers had left had been roasted and tasted
much more savoury than the berries
I gathered; I tried therefore to dress my food
in the same manner, placing them
on the live embers– I found that the
berries were spoiled by this opperation
and the nuts much improved. Food
however became very scarce and I often
spent a day searching in vain for a
few acorns to assuage the pangs of hunger.
When I found this resolved to quit the place
which I had hitherto inhabited & to seek for
a placeone where the few wants I expe
rienced would be more easily satisfied.
In this emigration I extremelyexceedingly lamented the
loss of my fire–I had obtained it by by strange
means and knew not how to reproduce it. by myself
This
this deficiency obtained my serious consideration for
several hours but I was obliged to leave it
relinquish all
attempts to
supply it, and wrappring myself up in my cloak
I struck across the wood towards the
setting sun – I passed three days in these
rambles and at length discovered the
open country – A great fall of snow had
taken place the night before and the
fields were of one uninform white the
appearrance was disconsolate and I
found my feet chilled by the cold dab
damp ^substance that covered the ground – It was about seven in
the morning and I longed to obtain food
and shelter. At length I perceived in a
small hut which had b doubtless been
built for the convenience of the
some shepheard. This was a new sight
to me and I examined the stustruc
ture of it with great curiosity. and
finding the door open I entered. An old
man sat it in it, near a fire onoverby
which he was preparing his breakfast
he turned of on hearing a noise & on
and perceiving me shrieked loudly and quiting
the hut ran across the fields with
a speed little of which his debilitated form
hardly appeared capable.of His flight
somewhat surprised me – but I was
inchanted with the appearance of the
hut. Here the snow and rain could not
penetrate – the ground was dry and wind
expelled and it appearedpresented to me then
as heavenly and divine exquisite &di
vine a retreat as Pandemonium appeared
to the tr dominions of Hell. after thier suffocation in the
lake of
fire. I greedily
devoured the remmnants of the shepherds
breakfast which consisted of bread, cheese,
milk & rhenish wine; the latter of which
however I did not like. Then overcome
by fatigue I lay down among some straw
& fell asleep.
It was noon when I awoke and allured
by the warth warmth of the sun I deter
mined to recommence my travels–&wrapping dep
depositing
the restremains of the herds bre peasants break
fast in a wallet I found, I proceeded
across the fields for several hours, untill
at sunset I came toarrived at a village. How mira
culous did this appear. The huts the neater
cottages & stat^elier houses engaged my
admiration by turns– The vegetables in the
gardensallured me and the milk and
cheese that I saw placed at s the windows
of some of the cottages—allured me— One of the best of
these I entered– but I had hardly placed
my foot insidewithin the door before the
children shrieked and one of the child
ren women fainted, the village was roused
some fled,—some attacked me untill
grievously bruised by sticks ^stones and all
many other kinds of missile weapon I
escaped to the open country and fear
fully took refuge in a low huthovel –quite
bare and making a wretched appearance
after the pallaces I had beheld in the
village.– This huthovel however adjoined a
cottage of a neat & pleasant appearance,
but after my late ^dearly bought experience
I dared not enter it. My place of refugeX
was the tool house and had not been
was not used for by the inhabitants of the ad
joining dwelling and was entirely shut
out from view by a pigstye on one
side and a dunghill & small spool
on the another – the two others were
formed by the wall of the cottage. Here
then I retreated and lay down happy to have
found a shelter from the inclemency
of the season & still more from the
barbarity of man
___________________________
was constructed of wood, &but so low that
I could with difficulty sit upright in
it. The f earth No wood however
was placed on the earth which formed
the floor of the cottage but it was dry
and although the wind entered by
innumerable chinks I found it an
agreable assylum from the snow
& rain
Chap. 2
As soon as morning dawned I crept from
my assylum to that I might view the
adjacent cottage and discover if I could
remain in the kennel that I had found.
It was situated at ^against the back of the cottage
and ^surrounded on its ^theopenthe sides which were exposed
by a pigstye & –crlear pool of water one
part was open and by that I had crept
in but now with stones and wood I cover
ed every crevice with stones & wood by which I might be
discovered ^ yet in such a manner
that I could move thenm on an occasion
to pass out; all the light I enjoyed came
through the stye and that was suffi
cient for me.
Having thus arranged my dwelling &
spr carpeted it with clean straw, I retired
for I saw the figure of a man inat a distance
and feared I feared remembered but
too well my treatment the night
before not to trust myself in his
power. I had first however provided
for my sustenance for that day by mean
by a loaf of bro coarse bread which I pur
loined and a cup w bywith which I could take
dringk more conveniently than from my
hand andofthe pure water which flowed by my
houseretreat – but tThe floor of that being
was a little raised & it ^so that it was kept ^perfectly dry and by
its vicinity to the chimney of the
kitchen fire of the cottage it was
tolerably warm. And bBeing thus provided
I determined to reside in this hovel
untill o something should occur which
might alter my determination. It
was indeed a paradise compared to
the bleack forest, my former residence,
and their rain dropping leaves ^branches ^& the dank earth. I ate
my breakfast with pleasure and was
about to remove a plank to procure
myself a little water when I heard
a step and looking through a small
chink a beheld a young creature
with a pail on her head passing
before my hovel. The girl was youn d g
and of gentle demænour unlike what
I have since found Cottagers and farm
house servants to be – Yet she was mean
ly dressed – a blue coarse ^blue petticoat and a
linen jacket being her only garb on her fair hair
was plaited but not adorned; she looked patient
yet sad. She passed aw away but in a quarter
of an hour returned, be bearing the pail which
was now partly filled with milk. As she walked
along seemingly incommoded by the burthen
a young man met her whose countenance
expressed a deeper desponcensdescesly; than her
uttering a few wordssounds with ain an air of
melancholy he took the pail from her head
and bore it into the cottage himself. She
followed wiping dry my her tears whi, and they
diasppeared – Presently I saw the young man
again with some tools in his hand cross the
field opposite the cottage and the girl was
also busied sometinmes in and som the cottage
and sometimes in the yard where she fetd
some ck chickens. and after some hours While
I examined my dwelling I discovered that part
of the cottage window had formerly occupied
a corner of it pu but the panes had n been
filled up with wood. In one of these was
a small & allmost imperceptible h chink,
through which howev the eye could just
peneatrate; and looking in I behe sa wthro this chink a
small room was visible, whitewashed ^& clean but very
bare of furniture & in co one corner near
a small fire I saw ^ beheldsate an old man sitting leaning
his head on his hand – in a disconslate atti
tude — X
his hair
was grey The young girl was co occupied in
arranging the cottage andbut presentlywhen that was
done she took somthing out ofthe a drawer
which employed her hands and ^& sat down beside the o the old
man who taking up an instur instrument began
to play and to produce sounds sweeter than
the voice of the thrush or nightingale. This chapter is too short
It was a lovely sight even to me poor
whec wretch who had never beheld aught
beautiful before. histhe silver hairs &
benevolent countenance ^of the more aged inhabit
cottager won my reverence
while ^the gentle manners of the girl enticed
my love. He played a sweet mournful
air which I percieved drew tears from
the eyes of the gen amiable gir l ^his you amiable companiontill her
of which the old man took ^no notice of it untill
she sobbed audibly – He the then pronounced
a few sounds and the poor creature leaving
her work knelt at his feet he rasied her
and smiled with such grace kindness &
love that I felt my own hard nervessensations of a peculiar & overpowering
move and I was obliged to withdraw from
nature they were anaturemixtureof pain & pleasure; such as as I had never experienced
my the hole. Presently the young maeither fromthehunger or cold, orfromor warmth or food and I
withdrewfrom my stationwithdrew
unable to
bearthese newthese
emotio nsemotions
Soon after this the young man returned
bearing on his sholders a load load of wood
ther girl met him at the door& helped
to relieve him of his burden and took
taking some of it into the fire cottage
placed it on the fire; & then she and the
youth went apart into a noknook of the cottage
and he shewed her a large loaf and a piece
of cheese.—She seemed pleased and went
into the garden for soome roots & plants
which she placed in water and then upon
the fire–. She thenafterwards continued her work &
whilst
the young man went into the pa garden
and appeared busily employed in digging & pul
pulling up roots– –After he had been employed
thus about hal an hour the young woman
joined him, & they returned to the cottage
together – The old man in the mean time
had been pe^nsive but on the approach
of the others ^his companions he assumed a penmore cheerful
air, and they sat down to eat. They quickly
finished their meal ^was quickly dispatched; the young woman was
again occupied in arranging the cottage the
old man walked before the door in the
sun for a few minutes, leaning on the arm of the youngthman
Nothing could exceed in beauty the contrast
between these two love excl excellent
creatures One was old, with silver hairs
and a countenance beaming with bene
volence & love; the younger was slimght
and graceful in his fu figure and
his feautures were moulded with the
finest simetrysymmetry – yet his eyes & attitude
expressed the utmost sadness and despon
dencency— The old man returned to the
cottage; and the youth with tools different
from those which he had used in the morning,
directed his steps across the fields– Night
quickly shut in but to my extreme won
der I found that the cottagers had a
means of prolonging light by the use of tapers
and was pleased to find that end setting
of the sun did not put an end I had to
the pleasure I experienced in watching the
my human neighbours.–In the evening
the young girl and her companion
were employed in various occupations;
thatwhich I did not then understand, & the
old man again took that instru
ment which produced thoese divine
sounds that had enchanted me in
the morning. and
wWhenSo soon as he had finish
-ed the youth began,– not to play,– but
heto uttered sounds which were monoto
nous and and far fromneither resembling the harmony
of the old mans instrument or the
songs of the birds I since found that
he read aloud, but at that time I knew nothing of the
science of words or letters. at that
time.
The family soon extinguished
their lights and retired, as I conjectured,
to sleep. rest
